This game will forever be remembered as the best single player sandbox I could have ever found myself playing - and that could be claimed through the level of dev support alone. Imagine Minecraft mixed with Norse myth and boom, you've got a little vikingr guy who busts down trees, builds homes, and defeats bosses. With friends, it becomes a tedious fighting tale of who can stay alive long enough for the other one to get back into the fight - or a grand slam of grinding for hours just to upgrade a weapon.
Here's my breakdown (and the game's not completed yet!)
Grindy = 12/10 (you might not love grinding but the satisfaction of completion is Massively worth it)
Building = 11/10 (there is creative mode!)
Mechanics = 9/10
Lore = 8/10 (to be continued with updates though!)
Brutality = 10/10 
Fun = 100/10 

This game will teach you that working hard in one biome will almost definitely be worth it going into the next - but that you have to earn the next one with just as much if not more difficulty. Super satisfying atmosphere for creative folks and also super satisfying if you love hoarding (I see you Skyrim players). Additionally, they have revolutionized the starvation aspect of games with hunger stats and they introduced tacking to a sandbox game (fantastic weather stuff going on in here guys).
I started the game back in initial release and I could not say louder that playing games while they're being developed and fine-tuned is a fantastic experience. 
Still don't know where the end will lead in Valheim, but I do know that it gave me a massive amount of respect for developers out there who continue to push their updates and lead with the community.

Great with friends! Consistent updates! Many free mods to enjoy. It's a "forever game" with many hours of playtime. There's always something to do; friends culminating the gathering of various resources for a goal. Building a house, crafting station, and more. Your friends can separately target a resource as an objective, or craft their own things alongside each other's. One may mine for ore, the other will chop wood, or hunt for food. You may terraform the world together, and pass each other's implements of being.

Valheim is one of the only "survival" games which makes tree-cutting, fun. There's a sense of purpose to your goals, rather than it feeling like a mindless chore. And it is all-so rewarding viewing the fruits of your efforts, in co-op or solo. However, at first, it can be quite daunting, not knowing what to do, where to go. You get a 'tutorial bird' to teach you about the world upon starting. It's easier to start playing with an experienced friend.

Each biome is a new world to explore. Bringing along new enemies, which use their own niche way of combat. The new elements to be found, will allow for creating better armour, weapons, and building materials. It works like a tier system; you will go from Biome A, to B, to C, each one preparing you for the next. There's even Merchants to be found!

The enemies are weaker to specific weapon damage, e.g from piercing, or blunt weaponry. Plan ahead, but all is viable! There's daggers, blades, hammers, bows. The worn armour can carry distinct passive skill bonuses, such as being able to stealth more quietly, or tank more damage.

Sailing; Luckily, you can create a portal system early on, so if your character dies whilst on another island, you can use a portal to get back your lost gear! This is important, because building a boat takes resources, which may not be found again in your starting biome.

The bosses drop unique buffs, which you can use one of at a time, in your singular skill slot. The importance of the skill you bring with you, is up to you. If you sail often, you may want to use the skill which provides wind direction. Skills have variable cooldowns to balance their strengths.

The world is randomly generated. World seeds are optional, of which can be used to generate specific worlds.

Valheim ‚Äì A Game That Captures the True Spirit of Viking Life

On paper, Valheim looks like a typical early-access survival game, but in practice it is much more than that. The game has a strange kind of soul. Its atmosphere pulls you in and you suddenly realize you keep saying ‚Äújust one more run‚Äù even when you planned to quit an hour ago.

Atmosphere and World Design

Valheim shines not because of fancy graphics but because of the mood it creates. It is honestly surprising how expressive a world can be with low-poly visuals. The forests feel peaceful. Rain feels heavy. Mist drifting in the distance feels like another creature watching you.

This is not a pretty postcard world. It feels alive.

Combat System

The combat is simple but satisfying. There is a sense of weight similar to Dark Souls. Timing your blocks, drawing your bow, closing in for melee hits‚Ä¶ everything feels grounded.

Boss fights are especially well designed. Each boss has its own identity and mechanics, and the game demands that you prepare properly before you face them. That cycle of ‚Äúget stronger for the next boss‚Äù becomes one of the most addictive parts of the experience.

Building System

The building system is surprisingly deep. Because the structures follow physical rules, a roof will collapse if it has no support. You are not just decorating a house. You are basically doing engineering work.

It gives you the real feeling of creating your own village from nothing.

Co-op Experience

The game is enjoyable alone, but with friends it becomes something completely different. Sharing tasks, improving your base, hunting bosses together‚Ä¶ Valheim‚Äôs true essence is in doing Viking life as a group.

Playing with others does not make the game twice as fun. It makes it ten times more fun.

Music and Atmosphere

The soundtrack is minimalist but perfectly placed. The gentle notes you hear while walking in the forest at night, the wind brushing past your building, the calming sound of rain‚Ä¶ These are not just background effects. They are part of the emotional backbone of the game.

Strengths

Amazing atmosphere
Satisfying and balanced combat
Physics-based building system
Epic co-op experience
Light system requirements
Endless sense of exploration

Weaknesses

Content updates can be slow
Playing alone can sometimes feel grindy
The huge map can overwhelm new players, although some people see this as a plus

Final Thoughts

Valheim is one of the rare games that manages to be both meditative and exciting. One moment you are relaxing at a campfire. The next moment you are fighting a massive creature with your heart racing.

It does not just use the Viking theme. It carries the spirit of it.

If you like this genre, do not skip it.

A big part of Valheim‚Äôs appeal is how fully it allows players to control the pace of the game. In most survival games, your situation constantly deteriorates: you go hungry, your food spoils, crops wither, and tools and buildings break and require repairs. You need to constantly do things to keep progressing, and it can feel stressful. In Valheim, you can‚Äôt die of hunger, repairs are free, food is imperishable, and crops and animals will wait for you forever. Aside from the occasional raid (which is usually easy to fend off), you can spend 50 hours just decorating your cozy base without consuming any extra resources.

This makes it easy to accommodate different playstyles. You can go as fast or as slow as you want. If you get bored building your castle, you can go out exploring. And when you want to take a reprieve from the intensity and danger of Valheim‚Äôs many biomes, you can return to some chill crafting or building project. That‚Äôs why I think it‚Äôs such a popular co-op game: people can do the things they enjoy and don‚Äôt feel like they‚Äôre not contributing. So if you‚Äôre looking for a ‚Äúfirst survival game to try the genre‚Äù or a ‚Äúsurvival game that can be played with non-hardcore friends,‚Äù Valheim is a great place to start.

If it gets too grindy for your taste, you can enable 2x resource gain in the world options at any time. You can also make combat easier (or harder) and change death penalties. When I was a child I used to cower in terror in the corner of our kitchen as my mother beat my sister with an enormous wooden spoon. I do not use the word "enormous" lightly, it was the sort of implement you would expect one to stir a witches cauldron with, or perhaps to scrape out the innards of a large mammalian carcass. I digress, this game is how I cope with my secondhand big spoon trauma.

A wonderful world to build, explore, and die in!

My favorite part is building. The structural support requirements are unique, intuitive, and fairly realistic without getting overly complicated. Those rules present good challenges to designing homes, bridges, towers, chutes to drop ore down a mountain, or whatever else you might imagine.

Its core gameplay elements aren't anything novel (collect resources, craft items, kill monsters, level up your skills...), but they are all well-executed and combined in a satisfying and engaging way.

I like that fast-travel (teleportation) is possible except for ore and some other important items. It means you still have to think about establishing routes and means of transportation across the map without making you have to traverse the map so much that you get bored.

I've found it unfortunately difficult to learn everything on my own. This turned me off from singleplayer for a while, since it wasn't clear to me what I should do to progress. There is a wiki online and a wiki built into the game, both of which can help with this, but I just don't find it very fun to have to read them so much.

Multiplayer has been especially fun though. Along with creating fun moments between players, playing with a friend who already knows the basics and can guide you via word of mouth has significantly helped remove the roadblocks on the learning curve for me.

Overall, 8/10, recommended.

While I have gotten good enjoyment out of this game, I cannot recommend it overall.

The further one progresses into the game, the less fun it becomes.
Combined with being way to grindy with default/recommended settings, this leads me to the downvote.

The game progresses via diffeent biome, with clear, strong equipment steps.
Each biome has it's own unique ressources, which are required for crafting equipment like armor, weapons and food (buffs).
One can only progress into the next biome if one has farmed enough material for the biome-specific equipment, and if one has upgraded it at least to some degree. 
In addition, one need to defeat a biome boss to gain key equipment opening up the next biome.

This progression system works excellently for the first five biomes (meadows, black forest, swamp, mountain, plains).
These five biomes are designed well - they each are uniquely fun to progress through, with their own unique challenges and design.
Even though, already in these biomes, there is an overly strong element of grinding - and made additionally grindly/cumbersome/slow by deliberate design choices like not being able to transport key elements through portals, if using default settings.

Then there are biomes six and seven - Mistlands and Ashlands.
With the Mistland, the grid becomes more cumbersome (you don't have to grind more materials - instead, the grinding itelf becomes more cumbersome), and some Mistland design choices do not mesh well with the games technical strengths and weaknesses (Valheim has issues with combat/hitboxes if there are elevation differences - and Mistland is all sudden elevation changes).

The game stops being fun, and is becoming a chore - a chore that feels entirely unneccessary, and seems to be down alone to specific, intentional design choices.

THUS, OVERALL, I DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS GAME.

There are some good points that I want to mention, as well:
- Combat is always engaging, fun and challenging (only exception is the mentioned hitbox issues).
- Excellent music and sound
- Game runs smoothly and is very stable (no crashes)
- First five biomes are LOTS of fun, if turning off portal item restrictions.
- If playing carefully, the rather stark death penalty (skill reduction) is ok. And the penalty can be reduced for a more causal play style.
- Fun both single-player as well as coop mutli-player with friends (host your own server).
- Dedicated Linux server is very stable
- Good selection of mods, if one is so inclined (I STRONGLY recommend the "DodgeShortcut" mod if playing with mouse and keyboard)
The penalty of dropping all of your gear due to dying is too much for this to be an enjoyable game for a casual player.

The combat and food systems are very good, and the game overall is very close to being great, but until these issues are fixed, I can't recommend buying the game

You move in a linear fashion through each area, starting with the meadows, then black forest, etc. In each area, you find new resources, unlock new recipes, fight new, stronger enemies, and summon a boss at the end that, when defeated, gives you the means to unlock the resources in the next area. Straight forward, right?

Here's the problem. The amount of resources you need is... excessive, especially if you're playing solo. It is rewarding being able to summon the bosses and unlock the next area, but by the time you reach the swamp biome, you realize that you're basically doing the exact same thing you were doing in the meadows, just now your equipment is made of iron instead of flint. I have never gotten past the mountain biome (the fourth area), so maybe it gets more interesting late game, but I don't have the patience to find out.

[h1]üö´ Frustration in the Fog: A Review of Valheim[/h1]

[b]Overall Rating: 1/10 (Not Recommended)[/b]

[i]Summary:[/i] While Valheim boasts an atmospheric world and engaging aesthetic, the core gameplay loop is crippled by [b]excessive, unnecessary tedium[/b], opaque mechanics, and frustrating quality-of-life oversights designed only to drag out playtime. I would refund it if I could, but giving the game a fair chance required sinking more than the two-hour limit.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]üò© The Grind Never Ends[/h2]

My main reason for not recommending this game is its overwhelming and constant tedium. I expect a slow start in survival games, with early progression focused on gradually moving faster, building more, and expanding possibilities. [b]Valheim rarely delivers this feeling of progress.[/b]

[h3]I. The Opaque and Punishing Progression[/h3]

The game introduces you to a beautiful world, but the accompanying hints from the Raven are often [b]frustratingly vague[/b]:

* [b]Vague Directions:[/b] Instructions like "You can find this specific item in a very dark place" are nearly useless. The location is an obscure dungeon entrance that looks identical to surrounding rocks, forcing the player to guess that "dark place" means the Black Forest and then rely on [b]blind luck[/b] to spot the entrance.
* [b]Boss Summoning Opacity:[/b] The game fails to communicate basic requirements for essential progression steps. The altar for the first boss gives [b]no indication[/b] of what sacrificial item is needed, nor does it tell you that you need [b]two[/b] of them. This forces players to either spend hours running around guessing or, more likely, consult an online guide.

[h3]II. The Crippling Material Loop[/h3]

The time sink surrounding metal acquisition is the most [b]egregious flaw[/b]:

* [b]Finding Ore is a Chore:[/b] Crucial materials like Copper Ore are visually indistinguishable from hundreds of normal rocks in a dense, enemy-filled biome.
* [b]Smelting Bottlenecks:[/b] After finding the required item in a dungeon, you often only have enough Surtling Cores for [i]one[/i] of the necessary buildings (the Smelter or the Kiln). Without a Kiln for Coal, the player is forced to spend valuable time [b]gathering food to burn for fuel[/b], drastically slowing the process.
* [b]Inventory Management Nightmare:[/b] Even if you succeed in gathering the raw materials, the weight restrictions are too punitive. Hauling enough Copper and Tin Ore to craft the first handful of Bronze Bars instantly [b]over-encumbers[/b] the player. You're also not allowed to use teleporters with ore in the inventory. Which means, you have to walk the whole distance (or use a ship) for no other reason than stretching the playtime and making it tedious. Sometimes the walk alone is several minutes. We are talking about a 20 Minutes Minutes session of which 10min are just walking.
* [b]No QoL Features:[/b] Compounding the weight issue, there is [b]no "Craft from Nearby Chests"[/b] feature. To craft even a small batch of 10 Bronze Bars, you must tediously move materials from a chest to your personal inventory, craft, and [b]repeat several times[/b].
* [b]Unecessary Big World:[/b] There is no reason for the world to be as big as it is. Walking is a chore. A horrible, tedious and boring chore. There is nothing to explore, no variety within the bioms, nothing unique to stumble across. The only reason to actually travel on the map is to fight a boss or do another tedious task; Getting resources. I've been watching valheim gameplay while playing the game and there are several youtubers which have 30 Minute long episodes of them just sitting half-afk in a boat, traveling to a boss. 

After defeating the first boss and unlocking the Pickaxe, it took me [b]three full hours[/b] of brain-dead gathering, smelting, and chopping just to get the Bronze Bars required for the [b]Axe upgrade alone[/b]. Upgrading the rest of the basic gear would easily require another three hours of this repetitive, joyless cycle.

[h3]III. UI and Combat Gripes[/h3]

* [b]Cluttered Crafting Menu:[/b] The crafting interface is an unsorted list without a search or sort function. To make matters worse, it constantly resets after checking an item's requirements, forcing you to [b]hunt for the same item repeatedly[/b].
* [b]Counter-Intuitive Combat:[/b] The dodge mechanic is poorly designed. It requires the player to be [b]blocking[/b] to execute a dodge roll, which defies the purpose of dodging as an alternative to blocking. Why spend stamina on an unnecessary block input when you could simply tank the hit or dodge directly?

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]

If i had to compare this game with another one; It would be Terraria. Both are games with a focus on gathering resources and fight bosses to progress. But somehow, it doesn#t feel tedious to gather resources in Terraria. Why is that? Because there is barelyx any downtime. There is no "sitting on a boat for 20min to fight a boss". There is no "walking back for 5min, after picking up 15 ores. The weight limit alone, makes the whole process unbelievable horrible. While increasing item drop rates might slightly ease the pain, because you have less downtime while gather the resources, it doesn't fix the fundamental problems of the downtime when getting from and to the base and other issues. Valheim's game design is [b]garbage on multiple levels[/b], prioritizing tedious resource gathering, traveling unecessary distances and obfuscated mechanics over meaningful survival or building gameplay. Unless you enjoy self-punishment, this is not a game to recommend.
